tariffs_v2.trigger_event: Alleged intellectual property theft and unfair trade practices by Chinese manufacturers
hs_product_categories: XV: Base metals and articles of base metal
tariffs_v2.previous_tariff_rate: 25% on semiconductors, 15% on solar panels, 20% on lithium batteries, 10% on electric vehicles
tariffs_v2.legal_basis: Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974
tariffs_v2.policy_objective: Protect domestic technology sector and address intellectual property theft
exemptions: Parts imported for completion of products to be exported
tariffs_v2.summary: The United States has announced a significant increase in tariffs on technology products from China and South Korea, focusing on semiconductors, solar panels, lithium batteries, and electric vehicles. The tariff rates will increase from their current levels to between 25% and 40%, impacting an estimated $85 billion in trade. The measures, based on Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, are set to take effect on April 1, 2025, and will remain in place for one year. The administration cited intellectual property theft and unfair trade practices as the primary justifications for these actions. Certain exemptions apply, including components used in medical equipment and defense applications.

articles.title: US Imposes New Tariffs on Asian Tech Products, Targeting Semiconductors and EVs
